dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the camera PANS inside, we see well-dressed men, women children (dressed 1985) seated in groups at big round tab We hear another voice.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Um, when Greg asked me to be his best man, I, uh, I mean I said yes right away, but I was kind of nervous... The toast goes on and on. We PAN past a bored bartender, photographer snapping pictures, various guests starting t lose interest, the GUY at the microphone...

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: ...I mean, Greg's my brother, man. He's really been there for me, I mean when IT was in rehab, when I had that problem with my car... When I got the baby-sitter pregnant... ...a goofy uncle with a video camera, guests kicking each other under the table, bridesmaids rolling their eyes and BRIDE, looking distressed. Finally, as the toast reaches sort of crescendo of pointlessness, the camera comes to r on the GROOM, his eyes narrowed in dull hate. The groom stands up, and the camera follows him across th floor as he walks over to the bandstand. There standing patiently, smiling, is the wedding singer, ROBBIE HART. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: ++-I got a lot of feelings inside me, man, and Greg was the only one, the only one to say, "Hey, fuck everyone else. You got to let those feelings out or your head's gonna explode..." The groom leans over and whispers in Robbie's ear. Robbie nods.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I mean I'm a person too Dad! God damn it, I'm a person too! He grabs a glass of water and then his mic. Robbie cuts off the GUY in mid-toast.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (very up) And a great person you are. The best man, everyone! Salud! Robbie raises his glass and everyone in the thankful crow follows suit. The tension is broken.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Love is really a miracle when you think about it. Here are two people that were born apart, raised and educated apart and then through some extra-terrestrial, or voodoo or something found one another and made that major vow to remain together. And here we all are to basically gawk at the courage and... and... faith it takes to make these vows to stay together forever. The BRIDE and GROOM sigh with relief, the entire room fil with the warmth generated by Robbie's love inspiring spee

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And I want you to know that even if you only stay together for forty or fifty years, I'll still be incredibly impressed. But the way you two look at each other and smile at each other, I got a feeling a thousand years wouldn't be enough for you. Cheers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie cues the band, they start thumping out a tune. A g named TIMMY is on bass, a guy named JIMMY is playing drum and a young woman in a billowy yellow dress named ERICA, wearing at least three scarves, is wailing away on guitar

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Now, on behalf of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fonda, I'd like to ask everyone to get on the dance floor and - celebrate! (singing) CEL-E-BRATE GOOD TIMES - COME ON!... As Robbie continues singing Kool and the Gang's "Celebration", we PAN TO a door, just to the left of the stage. JULIA SULLIVAN, a young waitress, comes blasting through it, two plates of prime rib in each hand. LAWRENCE, aka Dr. Limo the limo driver, Robbie's best fri sidles over to PHIL, the photographer. Lawrence points to Robbie. LAWRENCE. The maestro does it again. He has an incredible instinct for the quick save in a human drama.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Maybe he should be taking psychology instead of you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Interesting point. But I'd like to change the subject now to that waitress over there and her great body.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: She must be new.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Brand spanking new.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: i'm sure she'd appreciate you talking about her like she's a car. Julia precariously navigates her way through the crowd, finally arriving at the furthest table.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay, who wanted the prime rib? Everyone just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Nobody wanted prime rib? Everyone shakes their head.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: This table is all fish. Everyone nods.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Be right back. Julia starts making her way back to the kitchen with the plates. Robbie finishes up his song. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (genuinely enjoying himself) Well, all right! Hey, you guys dance nice. You know something, folks, I'm getting married myself next Saturday... Applause.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks. So, I just want to say that I hope that my wedding will be as special as Harold and Claudia's. Applause and "awwwww's".

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I really do mean that. One! Two! Three! Four! The band launches into "Everlasting Love".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia yells over to the chef.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Four fish! Julia's cousin HOLLY, who is also a waitress, comes over. Even though Holly's wearing the same uniform that Julia i she wears it a lot more "va-va-va-voomishly” .

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: How's your first night going, cuz? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You remember Mondale against Regan?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Don't worry, once we get the entrees served, it's all downhill. Coffee and cake is a breeze... Holly notices that Julia is near tears.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh, Julia, it's really not so bad. You just say “regular or decaf"...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's not that, Holly. Glen hasn't called me in a couple of days and with my track record I'm Mondale. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Only you could be this pretty and manage to find guys that treat you badly. I mean, just because dip shit hasn't called doesn’t mean he's ended it with you. Besides, let's say he did, it’s not the end of the world. Everybody's been dumped. Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Not by dozens of men.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You haven't been dumped by dozens of men.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: One, Brian. Went to jail for embezzlement. Two, Bob. Said I didn't love him because I wouldn't get fake implants. Three, Scott. said he dumped me because he didn't want to be . monogamous, but it turned out he was gay.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Have you ever thought of trying out one of those computer dating services?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Five, Danny. After ten months he said I looked too much like his sister. and now it looks like Glen is number six. Two years of my life wasted... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chef roughly slides four plates in Julia's direction.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: Four fish! As Julia struggles to pick up the plates, she speaks soft to Holly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I thought me and Glen had something special. Then again, I thought I had something special with all those guys, except maybe Scott. I'm just so sick of being somebody's latest girlfriend, you know? I'm ready for something more than that. My mother thinks I should've been married at least two years ago. She thinks I'm going to end up by myself watching re-runs of "Rhoda" with my nineteen cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie finishes up "Everlasting Love”. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Thank you! That was "Everlasting Love,” a special dedication to the bride from Eddie Davis... CUT TO the GROOM giving the BRIDE a suspicious look

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: We're gonna lay a little change of pace on you right now. Our guitarist, Erica Lamonsoff, is gonna sing an original song of hers called "Moon Child". Take it away, Erica! As Robbie bounds off the stage, Erica steps up to the mic begins singing a horrible, Stevie Nicks-ish "original".

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: (singing) DRUIDS DANCING ‘NEATH THE STARS, NO MORE FAMINE, NO MORE WARS... Robbie is walking towards the men's room when someone gra his arm, stopping him in his tracks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Hey, Robbie, remember me? I went to high school with you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. No, I don't. I mean maybe. I mean... Do I?

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Ah, you probably don't. I'm two years younger than you, I graduated in °81. But I was a huge fan of the band, man. You guys rocked! Remember when you played at homecoming and the cops came?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (smiling at the memory) Yeah, that night got a little outta hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: What happened to you guys? You were the best local band I ever heard. I thought you'd be touring stadiums by now. Yeah, you were my inspiration man. I mean, I'm an accountant all now, but I sometimes play gigs on Saturday night at the 119. Maybe you could come hear us sometime.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Sure, call me I'm in the book. You should really get your stuff out there man. You were really hot.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, we kind of drifted into this wedding stuff. But it's a lot of fun, I really like it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: That's cool. Hey, you still going out with Linda Lerner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I'm marrying her next week.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Congratulations, man! That's great.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (meaning it) Yeah. That is great. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: Hey, remember that song "Blood of the Goat" you used to do? That was great. Do you still write stuff like that? Robbie looks around, kind of embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm concentrating on writing some more serious stuff. You know, like, meaningful... In the background, Erica screeches out the chorus. Her so is neither meaningful nor good.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I didn't write this one.

dialogues.speaker: ALEC
dialogues.text: You must be a good writer though. You could probably write a song and sell it to a huge band like Foreigner or something.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Maybe someday. The songs I write now aren’t really... polished... Robbie trails off as he sees a TEENAGER across the room, clinging on to the wall for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a second. Robbie walks across the room to the Teenager, who is drun

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You all right, man?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: (far gone) Huh...?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You have to throw up?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: Yes, please.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie, his arm propping up the Teenager, guides him thro the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Code Red! Code Red! Everyone gets out of their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back entrance to the reception hall is a battered scr door at the top of stone steps, surrounded by dumpsters. Julia is sitting on the top step, taking a cigarette brea the sound of the reception muted in the distance. Another sound, that of rushing footsteps, can be faintly heard, but gets louder and louder until... Robbie rushes through the door with the Teenager, blowing Past Julia. He sticks the Teenager's head into one of the dumpsters; the Teenager starts to retch. Julia and Robbie make eye contact. Boing. For a few seconds, the only sound is the Teenager's retching. Then.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Me? No. I just saw what was about to happen. I couldn't let him do this in front of his friends and/or family. You know, the sound of vomiting doesn't tend to enhance any party, particularly a wedding. Julia smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad I got to hear it. The Teenager finishes retching. Robbie pulls his head out the dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: So are you ever going to drink again, kid?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: No, man, never. The Teenager staggers back inside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (shouting after him) Good. Remember, alcohol equals puke equals smelly mess equals nobody likes you... Equals driving under the influence equals drunk tanks equals rehab equals Ray Milland in Lost Weekend equals liver transplant equals do you really want to completely destroy your life? The Teenager's gone. Robbie and Julia are alone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You're the wedding singer, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm working your wedding next week.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You must be excited.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Very excited definitely.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Everything's going great for you, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is. “JULIA Could you do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Cut my head off.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, if I do can I keep it? Cause it's a nice head, with nice hair. Why, what's wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, 11.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I just moved to this crummy town to be closer to my boyfriend, and now I think he's dumped me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, but hey, he wasn't the right one then. The right one for you must still be out there.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: The "right one for me" must have skipped over me and settled for a college grad with a good job that comes from a wealthy family. I'm doomed to wander the earth, alone, forever...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Like the Incredible Hulk?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Only not helping people.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I saw you in there helping people, giving them fish and coffee and forks. C'mon people can't eat without forks, just like people can't live without real love. And for that you'll need your head.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (laughs) And once you've got a head you need silverware, especially forks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (laughs) I don’t know, you lost me back at the "Hulk". Erica is running down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: Robbie! We're on! Erica grabs Robbie and starts dragging him away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well, if I have to serve fish at least I get to hear you sing. Julia walks him to the stage. There is applause for a son

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Get up there and be great, wedding singer. And if by some miracle I ever get married, I want you to sing at my wedding. Robbie's touched.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: It's a deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Timmy are already on stage, vamping. Robbie and Erica walk quickly toward them. Halfway there, Robbie see something: the Bride and Groom, hidden from general view, having a heated discussion.

dialogues.speaker: GROOM
dialogues.text: Why did Eddie Davis dedicate that song to you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDE
dialogues.text: I have no idea! It must be some kind of crazy fantasy of his!

dialogues.speaker: GROOM
dialogues.text: All fantasies have a basis in reality! Hearing this, Robbie suddenly makes a detour to talk to t best man.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What's their song?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Their song! The song that they fell in love to! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh. I think it's that "Wham" song.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: “Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go"?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No, the other one. Robbie bounds up on stage, and whispers something to the band. They stop playing for second, then start playing a different, slower melody.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: We're back, folks. All right! We're going to start you off with a very special dedication to the bride and groom from each other... The Bride and Groom stop arguing and look up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: WHISPER, OF A GOOD FRIEND...
dialogues.text: The Groom takes his Bride's hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: PAIN IS THE HOLE YOU FIND...
dialogues.text: The Groom whisks his Bride onto the dance floor. The guests applaud.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing) ..-AND I'M NEVER GONNA DANCE AGAIN,... Julia, watching the whole thing from the door, is enchant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is playing the piano while teaching a singing less to a 70 YEAR OLD WOMAN named ROSIE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (continuing, quivering voice)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: {stops playing) Really good, really.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: You think so. Keep in mind this is for my 50th wedding anniversary so it has to be special.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I know Rosie, I know. Fifty years to the same person, what's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: The secret is no matter how mad you get at your spouse you can't leave.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: That's a big one Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Please, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Cause at some point people really can Grive you crazy, but if you stay till after that, it really gets good.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (excited) Really?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Really... And then it gets bad again. But after awhile it's no big deal. Acceptance that's the whole trick when people drive you crazy. I mean they can really irritate you, believe me. They sometimes just hang around, they have smells that aren't pleasant, nothing's good enough...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You do remember I'm getting married tomorrow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: —_—_—STrTwa ww 7 - eee

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Sure I do. I'm coming you silly boy. You must be very happy. I was so thrilled 1 got a rash.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Excited isn't even the word for it. This is the culmination of all my dreams. I mean, I guess alot of people say that. But for me... Well one day I hope to be singing, "If I Loved You," at my 50th wedding anniversary with Linda.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: You are a dear boy... Now I'll go get your meatballs. She goes to the kitchen and brings out a covered dish. Ro looks at it in disguised horror. He is however, as usual, extremely polite.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh no Rosie that isn't necessary really.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Come, come... you must eat them to be strong for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Rosie, I really have to...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Open the hanger... In the mouth they go... Chewy airplanes, spicy, spicy meatballs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Rosie, I really don't think... What about gas? Shoving the spoon at Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But... I'll never fit in my tux.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: No ifs ands or butts about it young man, you're going to eat this food just like always. Or I'll really give you gas. Robbie eats his first bite. It's horrible, he pretends to love it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Mmmm... terrific...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Isn't it wonderful. That's the tripe and the sour cream I think. There is a knock at the door. Robbie looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (crossing to door) Who could that be? She opens the door. It's Jimmy, Timmy, and the limo drive Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Not at all. We were just finishing...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Would you young men care for some meatballs? . Lawrence almost says yes until he sees Robbie's face.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No, no thank you. We came to take Robbie to his bachelor party.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Really? What a shame. Well, gotta go Rosie. See you on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want to take the food with you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No thanks, Mrs. Rosenberg.. It's catered. You know, beer and nuts. Well, we're going to be late. Bye bye...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Bye! You groovy groomba!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Bye!  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys have exited the house. Now Robbie stops them. A black stretch limo, with JIMMY and TIMMY in the back, i parked in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey man,thanks for the thought, but I told you I ain't going to any bachelor party tonight Linda would be really upset if I did that.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Well I'll be really upset if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: All a bachelor party can do for me is negative. There are no positives it can bring me.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Well it can positively get a stripper to bring me a boner. So get in the God damned car and let us have some fun. HE grabs Robbie and forcibly throws him into the limo. It immediately speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie leaves his bachelor party in full swing. As he ope the door in the background we can see Lawrence on all fou getting spanked by a fat, older stripper. He is moaning w too much. His other friends are drinking and dancing with strippers in the background. Robbie closes the door on this scene and heads up the blo to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie saunters up the sidewalk, eager to see his bride. Music can be heard comming from the house. Robbie crosses the front door and knocks. Linda opens the door in her wedding dress.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Man, you look unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Don't you know that it's illegal to see the bride the night before the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I think you mean bad luck and I think it's the wedding day not the day bef....

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Don't tell me what I mean. I know the bride rules and you know the groom stuff okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Sweetie, the good luck stuff has already happened... We're getting married, right? No bad luck can get us now.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I don't care what you think at this particular moment. I've thought about you enough to the point of marrying you. Isn't that enough? Jesus, you're a bottomless pit... I don't want to take any risks. So, if you don't mind, GO AWAY. Good night. Closing the door. Robbie stops the door from closing. He looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry I'm on edge. This bad luck stuff makes me nervous, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda, usually the bride and groom see one another at the rehearsal dinner, we're just not having one.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (patient) Yeah, but she's never in her wedding Gress. So, if you don't mind I'll see you tomorrow. She closes the door on him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (calls) Linda! C'mon! These are old wives tales. And you're not officially a wife for.... He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Seventeen hours. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (calls) And you're certainly not old... (pause) You look great! There is no response. The music goes on again. Robbie sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angie, Julia's mother, drives up with Julia dropping her for work. Angie is about 48, attractive, but bitter. Life not treated her that well. The car pulls up to the entrance where there is an easel photographs of Linda and Robbie announcing that this is t location of their wedding. Angie looks at the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay, mom, thanks alot, I'll see you lat...

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Look at the picture of that girl. See that? You're alot prettier than that girl and here she's getting married and you're still single. It's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Mama, please. Don't talk about this...

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Julia, you're not getting any younger. You need to find a man before your looks start to fade and your selection of mates becomes more limited. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But mom, you didn't get married til’ you were twenty eight.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: That's part of my point. If I married at twenty six I could've found a better guy than your father who wouldn't have left me. Why not marry Glen? He's good looking, got a steady job with income, he's charming.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: He hasn't called me mom. How can I marry someone that doesn't call me. Look, could we talk about this later? I've got to go to...

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Then call him. Get down off your proud high horse and let him know you care.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I thought you said men don't like aggressive females?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: That was in my day. Your generation is alot more androgynous. Females are more manly and males are more feminine. Look at that boy Scott you went out with. Julia leans over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Talk to you later mom. She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: (calls) Call him, Julia. You'll see I'm right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautifully decorated and full of people, there's definitely a wedding taking place. ADVANCE up the aisle, past the guests, up to the altar, r into an EXTREME CLOSE UP of the groom - Robbie. He is smiling broadly, happy, confident and proud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But then the first trace of something bad appears in his eyes. Soon the smile seems phony, it doesn't match the sa eyes. The music abruptly stops. The JUSTICE OF THE PEACE leans over and whispers in Robbi ear.

dialogues.speaker: PEACE
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should call the bride... Robbie's stares down the aisle toward the daylight stream in from the back door of the temple.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Something must've happened, I mean maybe the car broke down or she's stuck in traffic... or...or... there's a problem with her make up or dress or something... I know her, she likes to always look her best. Robbie seems to be in a trance, dreamily smiling and star up the aisle. After a few seconds, Robbie's older sister, KATE, enters a side door and walks across the otherwise silent church Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Robbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: {still smiling) Hi, Sis...

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hi, Robbie. I just got off the phone with Linda's mom. She's not in her room, but... there was a note.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, a note. Great.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: The note basically indicated that Linda was... not going to be coming today. Slowly, Robbie stops smiling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That's not very good, is it?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry honey, you want me to say something?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, I'll do it. Just give me a minute. Robbie crosses to the side door and goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie enters the room and crosses to a mirror. He stares himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the wedding guests are murmuring to one another in confusion. Kate and the Justice of the Peace stand at the podium talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie stands still in front of the mirror. He rips his t off, tearing his shirt. He punches himself in the face an is surprised at the pain.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You stupid fool. You stupid, stupid fool. He takes hold of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The confusion continues, we hear a large crash from the s room. Everyone becomes silent. Robbie enters the main roo He looks awful. Kate goes up to the mic and clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen I have an announcement to make...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (from side door) No, no, I'll talk. Robbie crosses to the center, murmuring reconvenes below. Robbie stands in front, clears his throat and begins spea loudly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Uh, hi, everybody. Linda, uh, well a note was discovered a short time ago, a note which seemed to... imply that Linda has gotten cold feet and will not in fact be showing up. Everyone reacts - "No", and says "how could she."

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No, thanks for sticking up for me, but I'm pretty sure that's the situation. Hey, nobody's more upset about this then Iam, believe me. Except Maybe you, Rosie. Rosie is sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: But, I'm sure Linda just has a little case of the jitters. We'll all be laughing about this next week, So we're going to make the best of this. Because you know something? Today is my nephew Todd's eighth birthday... Robbie indicates a kid in the crowd, TODD.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) -,-and he is going to have the most fun birthday party ever! So come on everybody... (singing)

dialogues.speaker: YOU...
dialogues.text: The crowd joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is sitting at the kitchen table of this small hous He has taken off his jacket and loosened his tie. His sis Kate is there and her husband, Andy, Lawrence and some of band members. Several nieces and nephews, including Todd, are chasing e other around the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sitting at the table with Robbie are his brother-in-law A and Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You have to let it out, Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Let what out?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: What you're feeling, you know. About what that lousy bitch did to you...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Watch what you say. I still might end up marrying her, and then there'll he some weirdness between you and me. Petey hands Robbie a large photo.

dialogues.speaker: PETEY
dialogues.text: I made this for you, Uncle Robbie. It's a photo of Robbie and Linda. Her face has been horri defaced.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, you shouldn't have done that, Petey... Very creative, though. Robbie walks out.

dialogues.speaker: ERICA
dialogues.text: I've never seen Robbie like this.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He was like this after we lost our parents in the car crash. But then once he got to high school and started dating, he opened up again.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: That's cause he thought a wife would give him kids and he could start a new family.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Limo.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hey look, this is just simple psychology. Usually it's chicks that are dying to get married. But Robbie's wanted to ever since I met him in the 6th grade. He (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE (cont'd) wanted his own family so bad he'd even marry the totally wrong girl.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hey, he'll bounce back. The guy's a born romantic.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Hey, check out the cake! Everyone turns to look at the wedding cake, which is on t counter.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There's just a little groom on top! Sure enough, at the top of the cake, where the miniature bride and groom usually are, the groom stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That's funny. Who did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is sitting alone on the porch. A convertible drivi by is blaring "Bringin' On The Heartbreak" by Def Leppard Robbie's staring at something hidden in his cupped hand. It's the tiny bride. LINDA appears in the driveway. She is wearing jeans and a sweater. She walks up the drive and stands in front of Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Look, this is for the best. You know why? Robbie doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Because, I'm not really in love with “Robbie Now," I'm in love with "Robbie Six Years Ago". The Robbie I knew back in high school, the Robbie who was going to be a rock star. I want to be Mrs. David Lee Roth, not Mrs. Local this. Robbie can't believe this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is 26.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda, that was a high school fantasy... We're all adults now for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Whatever. The point is, Robbie, I woke up this morning and realized... My God, we're never going to leave Arlington!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Who says I have to leave Arlington to make great music? Prince still lives in Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh, are you making great music, Robbie? Where is it? JI haven't seen it. All I've seen is a garbage can full of crumpled-up sheet music. stung.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda, this is a nice place. We grew up here, all our friends are here. Isn't it a good place to, you know, start a... family?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, what are we going to do? Raise kids in your sister's basement? And I'll spend weekends there alone while you're eff doing wedding gigs at sixty bucks a pop.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Eighty!

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Whatever. Robbie, stung, thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda... I love you... Isn't marriage about that? Isn't this about family? Isn't it about being there for somebody and knowing they would be there for you? I bet Davis Lee Roth doesn't have that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NN EE ell 27.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Well, I guess. But how can you worry about that stuff when you're just scrapping by, without a pot to piss in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well I can get a pot to piss in. I'll get a real job.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Look, Robbie, I have to go. Sorry about all of this. Take care. Linda walks off.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry too. Robbie throws the little bride into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia is walking down the sidewalk, a bag of groceries in each hand. She's listening to a Walkman. She is sadly singing along to Foreigners, "I've Been Waiting For A Gir Like You." In the BACKGROUND behind her we see a horse-drawn carriag enter from a side street, and turn onto the street she's walking down. The horse is moving fast. Faint "clip-clops get louder, the carriage gets closer. Finally, when Julia stops at an intersection, the carriage catches up. The horse's head is only a few feet from Julia. The horse whinnies réally loud. Startled, Julia turns and sees the carriage. It's being driven by a toothless old CARRIAGE DRIVER. The only passenger is a devilishly hands young man with a fistful of roses, GLEN GUGLIA.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Ta-da.

dialogues.text: Glen! You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Sorry... C'mon... Climb in. I have I question for you... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: on CLOSE UP ON the toothless old Carriage Driver turning

dialogues.speaker: CARRIAGE DRIVER
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Do you know how much manure a horse generates in a single day? CUT TO Glen and Julia in the back of the carriage. Glen looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Hey, professor, we're kind of busy right now. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIAGE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Twenty to thirty pounds. And that excludes urine.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Thanks for the info. Now, eyes front. The Carriage Driver turns around, muttering.

dialogues.text: Just trying to give you a good tour. Get ”~ your money's worth and I'm the bad guy. In the back of the carriage, Glens turns to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Anyway, you moving here to be closer to me shows that you take "us" very seriously, so I was thinking, hey, maybe I should do something to show that I take “us" seriously... Julia's starts to shine with pure hope. Glen fishes around in his pocket. He grabs something and holds it up. It's a diamond ring.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Jules, I think you're way better than all the other girls I ever dated... seriously.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yes, Glen. Glen slips the ring on Julia's finger. She looks at it in joyful awe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh my God... it's so beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought you'd like it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Glen, I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Congratulations Mrs, Weaver, you may now kiss the husband. LONG SHOT of Glen and Julia passionately kissing in the carriage, illuminated by the moonlight bouncing off lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a makeshift kitchen on one end and Robbie's disheveled bed on another. The room is extremely unkempt, clothes everywhere, dirty dishes, half consume@ jars of peanut butter, empty beer cans. Robbie lays unconscious across his bed fully clothed in a rumpled past caring way. There is anxiety, grief and sour milk in the air.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calls) Robbie! Robbie stir slightly in bed but does not awaken. Lawrence enters and takes in the horror that was once Robbie's comfortable room.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hey, you've been in that bed for five days now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Please leave.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I will, right after I see how soft those sheets are. Lawrence climbs into bed right next to Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hey, it's soft. Do you use Downey? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No. “All Tempa-Cheer". You can wash your clothes at any temperature and the colors won't run together. Now leave me alone. I'm unwell,

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: It's my breath right? That's always it. Drives away even the most tolerant people.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, yes, your breath does have a tendency to smell like horse shit twenty four hours a day. But I've grown to accept that a long time ago. I just don't want anyone in this bed right now. I'm trying to get used to laying in it alone.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My mission is to get a new chick to lay in that bed with you. That's why I'm taking you to work. You know there'll be over a hundred drunk girls at the wedding-all ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I live in my sisters basement. I don't make any money. I don't know anything about money. I don't even know what a mutual fund or CD is. How would any girl ever want to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Marry you? I'm just trying to get somebody to blow you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: There's no way I'm going. Lawrence abruptly rips the covers off Robbie and takes a Polaroid of his naked body.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I will show the whole town this naked picture of you if you don't get out of bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is reluctantly on stage singing to a receptive audience.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (sings monotone)

dialogues.speaker: 1999... TONIGHT WE'RE GONNA PARTY LIKE
dialogues.text: IT's 1999... The crowd applauds.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: That one goes out to the happy bride and groom, Jeane and Scott Prescott. Let's give ‘em another hand. Everyone applauds and whistles. We see the newlyweds smil and brush.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Your marriage is really off to a great start. I mean, Jeane showed up. So Scott, right away you must be pretty psyched. The Bride and Groom smile nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You know, Scott, she loves you just the way you are. Do you realize how cool that is? You don't have to be a big businessman or an astronaut or even a rock star to earn her love. She just flat out loves you. The Bride and Groom, relieved, smile more genuinely.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Then again...what do you do for a living, Scott? scott Uh, I’m a dentist. Robbie grimaces. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Ooo, yikes. Dentists make a ton of dough. Just keep an eye on her Scott. Separate checking accounts. And watch out for unexplained motel receipts. Two GUYS yell out from the crowd at Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, shut up and sing!

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey, whoa, it's interactive wedding entertainment! I talk, you talk. Except that I have a microphone... Robbie puts his mouth right up to the mic and bellows

dialogues.speaker: THING I HAVE TO SAY
dialogues.text: The crowd covers their ears. Robbie sits down on the stag

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Look, you two are lucky. Hell, I'm jealous of you. Some people will never find true love - like take for instance me. And I'm pretty sure that guy right there. Robbie points to a Forty year old fat man who is putting too much butter on his bread.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And that lady with sideburns. Robbie points to a mortified young lady with sideburns.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: So how about a toast. To wedded bliss. Enjoy it while it lasts. Lawrence walks up to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Some days are better left spent in bed. Robbie spots Julia from the stage. He doesn't want to be there anymore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: or ROBBIE (continuing) And now a special treat. An original song from our guitarists Erica "Moonchild." Robbie backs off the stage as Erica steps up.

dialogues.text: One, two, three, four...

dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: STRANGERS MAKING THE MOST OF THE DARK...
dialogues.text: He goes down the stage and approaches Julia who is just finishing serving drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: on Could you do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Cut off my head.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I heard about your... situation. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... well. Pretty much puts us in the same boat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well... oh well, yeah about that. My situations changed since then.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: No kidding...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Glen proposed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts 34.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, wow... Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Sorry? I'm glad. I'm really, really glad. I know I don't look glad, but that's only because I'm dead inside. But believe me, if someone is going to be happy it should be you. You're a nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It'll happen again for you, Wedding Singer. You'll see. What did you tell me? The right one for you must still be out there.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I used to say alot of stupid shit. You go on with your thing and T'll... see you. I don't want to bring you down. I'm afraid I might... contaminate you with the getting dumped disease.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. I'ma carrier, you | probably caught it from me to begin with. to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Robbie?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: keep your head, it's really a nice head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'll keep it for now, it's on probation. One more screw up and off it comes. He disappears through the crowd toward the stage just as Erica's horrible song is comming to a close. Julia watche him go wis tfully.  35.

dialogues.text: Robbie moves through another crowd on the sidewalk. He lo at a piece of paper with an address and looks up at a sig THE MUSIC FACTORY. He readies himself and pushes through doors.

dialogues.text: A complex of instruments for sale and music teachers for hire. A sign on the wall proclaims "Learn Piano and Guita and Voice in 8 weeks guaranteed with our accredited professional instructors. Results guaranteed or your mone back. First trial lesson free. We bring the music out of and it never goes back.” It is the MacDonald's of music. A woman approaches Robbie

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: May I help you sir?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah I have an appointment to see Joseph Brunk.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Back of the store on the right... Behind the synthesizers. Robbie moves through customers and salesman. Enthusiasm a hawking fill the air. He comes to the door of Joseph Brun Manager and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Come in! Robbie opens the door skeptically. Joseph Brunk is on the phone. He is a highly energetic salesman. As he talks he waves Robbie in and motions him sit in a chair across from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (continuing, into phone) Look, I feel bad for the lady, but her husband signed the contract. It's not my’ fault.... He winks at Robbie conspiratorially. Robbie squirms in hi chair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look pardner, I gotta run. A woman's work is never done, so you can imagine a real businessman's schedule... You to maestro. Keep alert. Red alert. Well red alert. Dive! Dive! Dive! He hangs up and comes around the desk to a bewildered Rob

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: (continuing, holding out his hand) Joseph Brunk, what can I do you for?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I'm Robbie Hart.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Yes... yes. The singing teacher. So, you want to be a franchisee?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Gotta do better than that. We gotta convince these people that we're doing them a favor to let them part with their money in exchange for some immeasurable musical skills. Subtle perhaps to the laymen, but to the truly musical their talent is finally exposed. A price can't be put on that. But we reluctantly do. Costly but fair. Think you wanna join our team?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Uh, how's the pay?.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Man after my own heart. The pay is great. Here's what we do, everyone signs a contract for thirty lessons in advance. If they can't pay, fuck em'. They'll only show up for three anyway. We have a no money back policy, so we're all set. We guarantee results, but we're businessmen. You see Robbie, it's not just that you teach people how to sing and make money. It's that you make money and occasionally teach people how to sing. Franchises are the future. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I'm ready for the future, I want to forget the past.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Well, welcome to the future see you Monday morning, 9am. Robbie starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Oh and Rob?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH
dialogues.text: Try and do something about the mood. You gotta lift it like a small, heavy plane. We don't want to bring people down. Bring em' down, they don't want to sing. Don't want to sing, don't want to pay. Don't want to pay, don't want to see you in my store anymore, okay?Get my drift?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE

dialogues.text: A very nervous looking Julia comes up the walkway readyin herself for her talk with Robbie. She heads down the flig of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia comes down the hall and finds herself in front of Robbie's door. The moment has arrived. She collects herse takes a deep breath and knocks. After a minute Linda answ the door wearing Robbie's football jersey with almost not on underneath.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Uh... well, yeah I think so, I was... She takes in Linda's attire and the ramifications of it.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You're... You're Linda aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yes. As a matter of fact I am. Linda Lerner. And you are?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Julia Sullivan. Is Robbie here by any chance?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he's indisposed. (smiles, whispers) Shower.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, God, I really wanted to...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Wanted to what? The two women look at one another. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just maybe tell him I dropped by. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I surely will. Julia.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thanks. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: {closing the door) No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is passed out on the bed in his shorts. There are scrambled eggs over at the stove. Linda has obviously mad herself at home. Robbie stirs hearing the sound of the door close.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (mutters) Huh? What's happening? Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Wrong apartment. Looking for your sister I think.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That's me. I've scrambled your eggs just the way you like them. Robbie sits up in bed, struggling against the sunlight. h has a slightly blackened eye. He does not look well.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Linda, what are you doing here? LINDA . I told you last night bunny, I realized my mistake and I'm so so sorry and I know I can figure out some way to make it up to you cause I want to come back. Robbie stares at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. 98.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You want to come back?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You slaughtered me in front of thousands of people and left me to die and now you want to come back.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Why don't we talk about this when you're feeling better.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I will never feel better than this regarding this topic. Linda, thanks for the eggs, thanks for the apology, thanks for the memories, please go.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (stops her) Nope, that's it. Conversation over. Get out of my jersey and go back to your life. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You don't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is shoved out of Robbie's apartment clothed, regain her balance.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Thank God we didn't marry Robbie Hart. Because you sir aren't who I thought you were,

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Maybe not. But at least I'm not a putz anymore. Besides, I realized I was never really in love with you cause now I'm really in love with someone else. He slams the door. Linda looks around to see if anyone sa She straightens herself and goes.  99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is in bed still asleep and bearing the mark of a sma bruise where J.D. hit him the night before. He is sleepin soundly, hungover, when Julia bursts in the room and jump the bed, shaking him awake.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Glen! Glen! Wake up! C'mon it's me... You have to wake up honey it's important!

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa baby... Where's the fire? Gimmie a second to get my bearings. He rubs his sore jaw.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It's just that I've been thinking about it and I thought why spend all this money on some big ceremony. I don't need a ceremony. Married is married, right? Through Glen's haze, the importance of what Julia just sa hits him. He smiles big.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: That's what I always said. But why this energetic change of heart?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: This is how I change my mind. It's enthusiasm. You know women. Some women when they want to do something, they want to do it. And I'm like that, this, sometimes. I just realized I've never seen Vegas and all those lights and we could have a heart shaped bed and all. We're not marrying a bunch of people, we're marrying each other. So let's go, the two of us. Now. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Right now? But honey, I haven't even brushed my teeth yet and... We've got to cancel things and...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Glen, do you love me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: I asked you to marry me didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Then brush your teeth, cancel stuff and let's go.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Fine with me. This is what I wanted to start with.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Rosie and Frank's 50th wedding anniversary. All the geriatric friends, children and grandchildren smile and s to Rosie's rendition of "If I Loved You". There are tears many guests eyes, including Frank. Robbie watches proudly from one side. Rosie stands center stage, Frank on her left, Robbie on h extreme right playing gently on the guitar. Rosie sings a well as we've heard her, with much warmth and confidence.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (continuing, singing)

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MIST OF DAY, NEVER, NEVER TO KNOW,
dialogues.text: HOW I LOVED YoU, IF I LOVED YOU... Everyone applauds wildly. Frank and Rosie embrace warmly. There is alot of emotion in the room. Rosie returns to th mic.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: As alot of you know that song was playing when I met Frank, who was dating my cousin at the time. If I loved him? Oh, I was mad about the boy. Too bad for Maxine, but she turned out to be a lesbian anyway... I think she's here tonight... (she waves) Hi Maxine! Agnes! Anyway, not to hog the mic anymore, I wanted to ask my singing teacher Mr. Robert Hart, without whom none of this, my singing, would be possible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: People applaud.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I wanted to see if he would play that special song he does so well by Mr. Al Green. Would you do it for us Robbie? Please? Robbie looks reluctant, but Rosie and the audience cheer on til' he arrives at the mic. Rosie embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Shake a tail feather, Mr. Hart. The band begins to play, Robbie begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: TO SPEND MY WHOLE LIFE WITH YOU...
dialogues.text: The old couples are dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is tapping on the dash board. Julia is looking very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: I can't wait to hit those casino's. Julia doesn't know how to respond. She nods awkwardly and looks out the window terrified. She is marrying a strange

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is still singing. Everyone is dancing. All the old couples are now making out. There is love in the air.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: WHETHER...
dialogues.text: The audience cheers, Rosie comes over and takes his face her hands. Suddenly, over the applause we hear J.D.'s voi come out of her mouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: J.D. / ROSIE
dialogues.text: I'm saying if you don't do it you'll spend half your life wonderin' what woulda happened if you did. Robbie looks at her in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: What did you just say?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I said thank you dear boy, you're my favorite human being. ROBBIE . Rosie, would you excuse me, please? I just remembered something of extreme urgency I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Give her my love. Robbie hugs her quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: You're the best. He turns to the band.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Gotta go guys. Something I really gotta do. You'll be fine without me.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER
dialogues.text: See you at Julia's deal tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER
dialogues.text: No, man, didn't you hear? That's been cancelled.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: When did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER
dialogues.text: Today, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: For sure? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER
dialogues.text: For damn sure.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Okay, bye. Thanks guys... Robbie is smiling as he charges through the guests and ou the reception hall. Rosie smiles watching him go.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, RECEPTION HALL
dialogues.text: Robbie runs out of the reception hall en route to his cra car. Lawrence drives up in his limo.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (calls) Hey buddy, wanna ride? Robbie smiles at the sight of his friend. He runs to the and jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Take me to Julia's. She cancelled her wedding!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Well, she may have cancelled the ceremony, but I just took some folks out to the airport and I saw Glen and Julia checking in for a flight to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Shit! Damn! All right... All right... Change of plan. Go to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? Hijack their plane?

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: I'm going to do something. I'm formulating my plan, okay. Just... let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen and Julia are boarding their flight.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Here we are 3A and 3B. Glen heads for the window seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Honey, would you mind letting me sit in the window seat? I've never seen Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Oh baby, no can really do. I hate the aisle. That drink mobile brushing my big shoulders, on top of every high roller. You're a dainty thing, they won't crush you as much. Tell you what, you can lean over me when we fly over the strip, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (faintly) Sure. Glen nestles into the window seat. Julia sits ina funny position at his side, not wanting to touch him with her b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is on the phone to Holly finding out the details o Julia's whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where? The Treasure Island Wedding Chapel... Eight o'clock... got it. Thanks Holly, you're the best... - I'll tell him. He hangs up and turns to Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) She said you left your underwear at her house. Lawrence barely reacts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I assume she's kidding. They arrive at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We did it pal. We did it all night.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: And she didn't mind your breath? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I had my tongue scraped. Worked like a charm.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Good luck. He smiles and drives off. Robbie runs into the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen and Julia get into a cab with their overnight bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is now on the plane. He has piece of the paper Jul gave him and a pen. He is trying to write a love song for Julia and getting a little attention in the process.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the glittering lights of Vegas fail to illuminate Jul downcast demeanor. Glen is itching to get his fingers on lucky cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie is comming of the plane and moving fast. A man wit mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia and Glen head towards the Treasure Island Chapel. T arrive at the door. The sign reads, "Walk the Plank At Treasure Island".

dialogues.speaker: GLEN
dialogues.text: Well babe, here we are. Let's do what we gotta do. Julia looks at him in horror.  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie strains forward as if to get to the hotel quicker.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Can't you go any faster?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I have been informed by the state of Nevada that any further traffic infractions will result in the suspension of my license. Settle down kid. Whatever it is it'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (sits back,to himself) Not this... The cab arrives at the Treasure Island Hotel and Robbie j out of the cab. He pays the driver and runs into the hote clutching his pieces of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbie tears into the hotel and locates the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (breathless) Can you tell me where the chapel is? I'm looking for the Guglia wedding... Glen and Julia Guglia.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: dust one moment, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: Julia Guglia... ugh, one more reason she can't marry this asshole. She disappears and consults a computer. Robbie can't stan the waiting. He is bursting. In the background we hear a jackpot bell ring and.a woman's voice screaming. The receptionist returns.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir, that wedding has already taken place. It was scheduled for eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) Are you sure? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. Robbie starts to walk away from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Thank you. He looks around and finds the most convenient bar and cro to it. INT. TREASURE ISLAND BAR - NIGHT - cont. ACTION Robbie stands at the bar with what little enthusiasm he h left for life and he looks around. Suddenly he sees, he thinks he sees, someone that looks like Julia sitting alo at the bar. He moves around to secure a better vantage point and sees that yes, it is Julia. His mind races, he spies the band is a smattering of applause. The Guitarist steps up to th mic and makes an announcement.

dialogues.speaker: GUITARIST
dialogues.text: And now a friend of ours from out of town would like to dedicate a song he wrote for Julia. The Guitarist hands Robbie the mic. Julia looks up, at fi confused, then amazed, then delighted to see Robbie there

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (into mic, clears his throat) This song is tentatively entitled, "r Love You So Much That Nothing Else Matters In My Life But You, You're A Goddess, A Miracle, An Angel With Wings, And Holy Shit You smell Good", (looking sheepish) I realize it's a long title, but I'm working on it. The band starts to play as Robbie sings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing, singing)

dialogues.speaker: SONG...
dialogues.text: The audience applauds. People push her on stage She hugs

dialogues.speaker: ROBBIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where's Glen?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I couldn't marry him. He doesn't have a soul. They kiss, the softest longest best kiss a lounge in Vega has ever seen. The audience cheers and someone else hits jackpot and screams life is good.
